data.title: Wonderful collection of full size dinosaur skeletons
data.text: This building was a former Post Office - beautiful building from the turn of the century.  Dinosaurs from around the world with easy to read descriptions

data.title: Kid Friendly Museum
data.text: It is a great little museum for children.  The big dinosaur in the museum catches children by surprise.  They should open up fossil digs for children and not just school trips.  They might also want to add more exibits.

data.title: Small, but interesting for kids
data.text: We heard about the Dinosaur Discovery Museum, when we were being given a ride on the streetcars and the pilot/operator told us how good the Dinosaur Discovery Museum was for kids.  So, when we came to the streetcar stop, we got off and headed to the museum.  In front, are the dinosaur statues which always make for good photos with the kids.  The exhibit floor is small, but it was especially perfect for smaller kids.  The exhibits are well thought out and informative and all of us found it interesting.  We were told about the kids activity center in the basement, so we headed down there to check it out and there were a couple of activities for the kids, as well as a viewing area of their laboratory or work area.  While we were downstairs, one of the volunteers, Mason, came out and was very personable and friendly and entertained the kids with a variety of bones, replicas and teeth.  They really enjoyed Mason and he is a definite asset to the museum.  Though the museum is free, they do ask for a donation.  There is a small store on the first floor near the entrance and everything was reasonably priced.

data.title: Go in with the intention to learn and you'll likely be entertained!
data.text: We visited the Kenosha Dinosaur Discovery Museum on a Friday afternoon. It was a beautiful building and we were welcomed by a really neat statue of a Dilophosaurus standing outside of it. The admission was free with a “suggested” donation of three dollars which we paid before looking over some of the fossils featured in the same foyer. For those willing to take the time to read the stories behind these specimens, it provided a fascinating glimpse of creatures that once lived in the North America West/Southwest some 65 million plus years ago. Ironically, I’d visited that region a couple of months earlier and most of their museums offered fossil casts while Kenosha boasted many authentic pieces. We entered a large room that served as the main dinosaur attraction. It claimed to have the largest collection of meat-eating dinosaurs on display and I, for one, believe them. Aside from the more commonly seen T-Rex and Allosaurus, they also showcased much rarer dino casts of such as Carnotaurus and Suchomimus. If you don’t recognize any of these names don’t worry, you’re kids probably do. Amid the two-legged terrors are fun and informative signage that offers amazing insights to a family of dinosaurs that likely branched into our modern day birds. This attraction is definitely tailor-made for dino-loving kids and those of us adults who are still kids at heart. I think if you go in with the intention of being entertained you may be disappointed but if your goal is to learn something new then you’ll likely be entertained. All in all, a free and fun way to spend the afternoon.

data.title: very  boring
data.text: theres nothing  worth  seeing there   its a waste  of time  it takes about five minutes too walk the place.

data.title: great Local Venue
data.text: great local place to take the kids or to meander with a friend. Interesting place. Jump on the trolley afterwards for a trip around town.

data.title: Enjoyed the Exhibit.....
data.text: My family and I were pleasantly surprised by this exhibit that had large displays and plenty to look at.

data.title: Great For young Children
data.text: My Grandson and I visit the Dinosaur Museum and I learn a lot about dinosaurs!!! Fun, fun, fun; we took plenty of pictures, would try to load some later.

data.title: Good and absolutely free
data.text: My kids loved this museum. My son who is 4 years old, loved to see all the dinosaurs. It is free and very close to Kenosha public museum and civil war museum.

data.title: Small but free
data.text: It was cute.  I wouldn't make it the only stop of the day but it was clean, cute and free. I had teenagers so they were not impressed but I enjoyed it and I'm sure younger kids would have too.

data.title: Free and great dino's
data.text: We went when all of the Dino people were on a site excavation. The kids had a good time and it was free. Would be better when they palentologists were in residence.

data.title: Enjoyed our visit...interesting!
data.text: Small inside, but packed with dinosaurs!  You can't beat free admission either.  Located inside a vintage post office building with great historical charm. We spent about 30 minutes looking at the displays and small gift shop.  Great for a quick stop while in the Kenosha area.  Pair it up with a trip to the Public museum downtown and a stop at the lighthouse on the pier for a FREE afternoon!

data.title: Worth checking
data.text: It contains one hall with several skeletons of dinosaurs. Since my little son is crazy about them we had to visit. Admission is free (donation if you wish) You can take some cool pictures and read brief notes about each displayed skeleton. Whole visit wont take more than half hour.

data.title: Good Family Time Adventure for the children!
data.text:
Nice place to take the grandchildren - they really enjoyed it!

Doesn't take a long time so they don't  loose interest.

data.title: Its beautiful city and amazing Museum...
data.text: Its beautiful city and amazing Museum... Good for kids as it is dedicated to the exploration and explication of the relationship between modern birds and ancient carnivorous biped dinosaurs, the theropods, which include Carnotaurus, Tyrannosaurus rex, and Velociraptor.  this place has small gift shop as well.. its free admission and free parking

data.title: A Quick Trip
data.text: Other reviewers have said that this is a small place, and I agree, but I think your experience depends on how you approach it.  My daughters and I had a great time at this place, because we didn't expect too much and we made our  own fun.

data.title: Nice, quick stop for dino lovers
data.text: Found this place while driving through Kenosha and had to stop. It's a small place, but the exhibit is very well done and informative. The docent was very knowledgeable and friendly. The full skeletons are replicas, but they have some authentic fossils as well. It's a quick stop, but definitely worthwhile, especially if you have a dinosaur fan in the family.

data.title: Dinosaur excavation in basement
data.text: It was fun with small children, ages 4 and 6, to "excavate the dinosaurs" in the basement.  The first floor was also very impressive for the children and showed them how large the dinosaurs were.

data.title: Not a whole lot to see or do
data.text: This is a free museum, but there wasn't a lot to see and do. The kids did enjoy seeing the dinosaurs inside and outside.

data.title: A meek museum
data.text: Though it's just one hall, the way they displayed the Dinosaurs utilizing the whole space was perfect.
